Not sure if I should have chosen the "launcher" component when creating the 
defect, but here goes:

Using CDT Build 200406140300 running on Eclipse RC2 build (200406111814)
Running on Windows XP, but also saw same behavior on Windows 2000.

I create a managed C project that contains just these few lines of code:

#include <stdio.h> 

int 
main(int argc, char **argv) {

	int anyNumber = 0;

	printf("Hello from MgdCpp\n");
	printf("Enter any number so that I can terminate\n");
	scanf("%d", &anyNumber);
}

After successfully building it, I create a run configuration and hit the Run 
button. I don't see the expected output in the console or in a command prompt 
window, and the only indication that something has been launched is that the 
Red button (which one pushes to terminate the program) is now present in the 
console title bar. When I press that button to terminate, I get the following 
log:

Now if I choose "Debug..." instead of "Run..." in the Run menu and debug the 
same executable, a command prompt window opens and the program runs and 
terminates properly after doing the required output and input.

If I comment out the last line of the program (the scanf line) and then run 
the program, I see the expected output in the console window before the 
program terminates normally. Don't know why the scanf causes this behavior, 
especially since its only when "running" as opposed to "debugging"
The problem is that Console View is buffered.
(Someone else can decide if that's a defect.)

If you add the extra line:

	 printf("Enter any number so that I can terminate\n");
	 fflush(stdout);  /* ADD ME */
	 scanf("%d", &anyNumber);

You will see Console View is acting as stdout/stdin for your app.
Of course, there's probably more polite ways to terminate a process
that don't cause IOExceptions.
The exception still occurs on 2.0 GA.
PR was not targeted to any particular release. Changing target milestone to 2.1
The buffering of stdout is bug 27663.
